FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[ReleasePrep][2022.04.11] RI dev to main" (#9090) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Make sure account and package links on the support requests page use the same host" (#9089) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Admin-only instance in support requests links accounts and packages to the originating host (www.nuget.org) which creates complications for processing support requests.
This change replaces absolute URLs with relative ones that works around the issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Cannot compile NuGet.Client due to duplicated PackageReference" (#11738) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

VS Version 17.3.0 Preview 1.0 [32410.47.main], NuGet 6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Clone NuGet.Client to dev in commit: e70d3c6167fc1c878acee98050784726152e4a31
1. Open Dev PowerShell for VS 2022 IntPreview
2. Run `cd path\to\repo`
3. Run `git clean -xdf; .\configure.ps1 -Force; .\build.ps1 -Fast -SkipUnitTest -Binlog`

### Expected

Code compiles

### Actual

```
C:\src\NuGet.Client.pmc\test\NuGet.Clients.Tests\NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.Test\NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.Test.csproj : error NU1504: Duplicate 'PackageReference' items found. Remove the duplicate items or u
```

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Attaching binlog
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: TargetFrameworks netstandard2.0 does not set TargetFramework for inner build" (#11721) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 17.1.0+ae57d105c for .NET Framework

### Worked before?

Yes, but not sure what broke it

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

 I run msbuild l10n.proj /t:ReportVariables /verbosity:detailed with l10n.proj having these contents:
```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NuGet.CommandLine" Version="6.1.0" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
  </ItemGroup>
  <Target Name="ReportVariables" DependsOnTargets="restore">
	<Message Text="TargetFramework=$(TargetFramework)" />
	<Message Text="TargetFrameworks=$(TargetFrameworks)" />
	<Message Text="ExcludeRestorePackageImports=$(ExcludeRestorePackageImports)" />
	<Message Text="PkgNuGet_CommandLine=$(PkgNuGet_CommandLine)" />
  </Target>
</Project>
```
And get this [output](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/8443894/verbose.output.txt)
Here is the generated [l10n.proj.nuget.g.props](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/8443875/l10n.proj.nuget.g.props.txt) file.
It looks like it is generating that file correctly for TargetFramework netstandard2.0.

Note that while TargetFramework is set properly during the parts of the build that happen during the restore, it is not set at the end when building the **ReportVariables** target. Therefore, the PkgNuGet_CommandLine variable is also not set.
The above is a stripped-down sample project file. The original is [here](https://github.com/sillsdev/libpalaso/blob/master/l10n/l10n.proj).
I tried it on my current laptop and my old one (where it used to work, but possibly with an older tool set), which has VS 2019 (msbuild engine version 16.11.0+0538acc04). The only significant change to the project file itself was a few days ago, in an attempt to fix problem: "The target "GetVersion" does not exist in the project". Looking at the generated l10n.proj.nuget.g.props file created with that version, it was apparently targeting net461 instead of netstandard2.0, so my guess is that the newer tool sets stopped paying attention to TargetFramework, in favor of TargetFrameworks. It seems that changing TargetFramework to TargetFrameworks and moving from the deprecated GitVersionTask to GitVersion.MsBuild worked for the developer who did it, but it is still not working for me.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PRI error on building NuGet package" (#11693) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

Other

### Describe the bug

Facing PRI error when building the NuGet package. It is because changes in the dependent library#1 will not be updated into library#2.

Project structure

App1

- library#1
- library#2 (using library#1)

I'm referring to the latest library package whenever I'm opening App1. Here I'm facing an error in the below scenario.

<html>
<body>
<!--StartFragment-->

Scenario | library#1 | library#2(Depends on library#1) | Comments
-- | -- | -- | --
Changes in library#1 cs file | library#1‚Äì version2 | library#2‚Äì version1library#1 ‚Äì version1 | Working fine
Changes in library#1 XAML file | library#1 ‚Äì version2 | library#2‚Äì version1library#1 ‚Äì version1 | It shows PRI error
Changes in library#1 XAML file with the same version | library#1 ‚Äì version1 | library#2‚Äì version1library#1 ‚Äì version1 | Working fine but changes are not reflected
No changes in library#1 but changes in version | library#1 ‚Äì version2 | library#2‚Äì version1library#1 ‚Äì version1 | Working fine

<!--EndFragment-->
</body>
</html>

We have the scenario "If there is one change in library#1, then we need to repack multiple libraries like library#2. Otherwise it shows PRI error". Is that any other way to resolve this issue?



**Sample and package:** [pri error.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/files/8347630/pri.error.zip)

### Repro Steps

1. Open the provided sample
2. Install the package provided
3. Build the sample then it shows PRI error 

### Expected Behavior

- It should not show a PRI error.
- For changes in one library, we should not repack multiple libraries.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Install-Package using package consumer-provided casing not package owner-provided casing" (#11735) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

17.1.1

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a new .NET 6 project
2. Open PMC
1. Type `install-package system.linq.async`
1. Wait for command to complete
1. Open .csproj

The package ID casing is not the original from NuGet.org. Instead, it's casing that was provided in the command line.

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="system.linq.async" Version="6.0.1" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

### Verbose Logs

```
PM> install-package system.linq.async
Restoring packages for C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\VmDeploy.csproj...
Installing NuGet package system.linq.async 6.0.1.
Writing assets file to disk. Path: C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\obj\project.assets.json
Restored C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\VmDeploy.csproj (in 30 ms).
Successfully uninstalled 'Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces 1.1.1' from VmDeploy
Successfully installed 'Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces 6.0.0' to VmDeploy
Successfully installed 'System.Linq.Async 6.0.1' to VmDeploy
Executing nuget actions took 174 ms
Time Elapsed: 00:00:00.3298956
```

### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

17.1.1

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a new .NET 6 project
2. Open PMC
1. Type `install-package system.linq.async`
1. Wait for command to complete
1. Open .csproj

The package ID casing is not the original from NuGet.org. Instead, it's casing that was provided in the command line.

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="system.linq.async" Version="6.0.1" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

### Verbose Logs

```shell
PM> install-package system.linq.async
Restoring packages for C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\VmDeploy.csproj...
Installing NuGet package system.linq.async 6.0.1.
Writing assets file to disk. Path: C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\obj\project.assets.json
Restored C:\Users\jver\Desktop\VmDeploy\VmDeploy\VmDeploy.csproj (in 30 ms).
Successfully uninstalled 'Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces 1.1.1' from VmDeploy
Successfully installed 'Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces 6.0.0' to VmDeploy
Successfully installed 'System.Linq.Async 6.0.1' to VmDeploy
Executing nuget actions took 174 ms
Time Elapsed: 00:00:00.3298956
```
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: PM UI version list only shows a single latest version" (#11734) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

17.2.0 Preview 3.0 [32407.349.d17.2] 

### Worked before?

Yes, works in 17.1.1 and 17.3.0 preview 1.0

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Open PM UI for a .net project
1. Switch to Browse tab
1. Ensure NuGet.org is the selected source
1. Search for `azure.resourcemanager`
1. Observe the version list menu

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/162587120-48259e2f-33a6-46fa-95eb-473e7556afc9.png)

It should show many versions, not just one.

I was unable to use "Report an issue" in VS because that option made VS lock up. I'm not sure how to report that.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
